node.title: Back to the Future (of Drupal)
node.excerpt: Boris will be presenting on Drupal and the Decentralized Web at DrupalCon Minneapolis, May 18 - 22.

node.plaintext:
After a long absence from the Drupal community, I've been accepted as a speaker
at DrupalCon Minneapolis [https://events.drupal.org/minneapolis2020/]. I'll be
presenting about Drupal and the Decentralized Web, and some of the changes that
have happened from the past to the present on a number of topics, including open
source licenses, a shift in architectures and hosting, the rise of the
advertising supported web, and what a more peer-to-peer future holds.

Update:  DrupalCon Global has been rescheduled as a fully online, distributed
conference. I will miss the opportunity to catch up with many people in person.
But I have been lucky enough to have my Drupal and the Decentralized Web
session
accepted as a "live" talk
[https://events.drupal.org/global2020/sessions/drupal-and-decentralized-web],
taking place on July 14th at 23:15 UTC / 4:15pm PDT / 7:15pm EDT. Please join me
at the conference and for my session, I've added it as an event on our forum as
well
[https://talk.fission.codes/t/drupal-and-the-decentralized-web-boris-mann-drupalcon-global-july-14th/729]
.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Back in 2003, I joined drupal.org, posted about wrapping recipe.module with CSS
classes [https://www.drupal.org/project/recipe/issues/2524], and the rest is
history.

> Happy 16th birthday, Drupal! üéÇüéà https://t.co/eTO1JMvxTQ  
pic.twitter.com/Q57SXfQQIY [https://t.co/Q57SXfQQIY]

‚Äî Dries Buytaert (@Dries) January 15, 2017
[https://twitter.com/Dries/status/820624651344809984?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw]
Dries presenting in Vancouver in November 2004, in a tweet from 2017. Drupal is
19 years old this year!I went on to host Dries in Vancouver [https://dri.es/album/vancouver-2004/]  in
2004, along with the first printed Drupal t-shirts, a beer tower
[https://dri.es/album/vancouver-2004/pub-beer-tower-2], and the folks from
DeanSpace / CivicSpace (working on the Democratic primaries) flew up to join us.

Allow me some brief nostalgia‚Ä¶


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I founded Bryght
[https://www.drupal.org/forum/general/news-and-announcements/2004-08-30/who-are-these-bryght-guys]
, one of the first commercial companies focused on Drupal, helped organize many
more DrupalCons and DrupalCamps, and helped found the Drupal Association.

FOSDEM 2005, before which the first DrupalCon had about 40 peopleWe were in the
thick of Web 1.0 transitioning to Web 2.0, and the early days of identity
standards and communication between websites. That post I made about the 
recipe.module  is actually tied to a Blogger.com account, which at the time you
could use to login to drupal.org.

Open source licenses and the details of GPL were hotly contested, and we faced a
lot of FUD from Microsoft and others. A global community using mailing lists and
IRC was forming, and we didn't know what we were doing was new and different,
but that we had come for the code and were staying for the community.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now, I see Web3 emerging ‚Äì although the blog post where I attempt to define what
that means to me still isn't finished yet!

New open source licenses are emerging (Dries on Makers and Takers
[https://dri.es/balancing-makers-and-takers-to-scale-and-sustain-open-source]),
business models beyond the advertising supported web are being sought for.

Advances in computer science theory have given us new tools for distributed
systems and cryptography, leading to both better privacy and programmable
Internet money. 

Dries' post on low-code and no code tools
[https://dri.es/low-code-and-no-code-tools-continue-to-drive-the-web-forward] 
shows more changes that I think fit into this theme:

> When everyone is a builder, more good things will happen on the web. I was
excited about this trend more than 12 years ago, and remain excited today. I'm
eager to see the progress no-code and low-code solutions will bring to the web
in the next decade.
The Drupal community has long been eager to experiment with new technology and
standards. How will Drupal's traditional LAMP stack architecture fit with
serverless and decentralized approaches? What new standards and protocols make
sense to integrate and expand on?

What new experiences do they enable that offer benefits for everyone from site
builders to Drupal end users?

Please join me in Minneapolis for my presentation Drupal and the Decentralized
Web
[https://events.drupal.org/minneapolis2020/sessions/drupal-and-decentralized-web]
. Check out the full list of speakers
[https://events.drupal.org/minneapolis2020/speakers]  and accepted sessions
[https://events.drupal.org/minneapolis2020/sessions/accepted].

I'd love to catch up with many of you that I haven't seen for years, and to meet
many new members of the Drupal community.

"The Drop is Always Moving" is about Drupal always changing and evolving. Image
from the @DropIsMoving [https://twitter.com/DropIsMoving]  account.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Want to find out more about what we're up to with Fission
[https://fission.codes]? You can read the latest newsletter in our forum
[https://talk.fission.codes/t/newsletter-fission-product-update-fission-drive-preview/505]
, or drop into our Discord chat [https://fission.codes/discord]  to come say
"hi" (plus I'm in the Drupal Slack, too).
node.html:
After a long absence from the Drupal community, I've been accepted as a speaker at DrupalCon Minneapolis. I'll be presenting about Drupal and the Decentralized Web, and some of the changes that have happened from the past to the present on a number of topics, including open source licenses, a shift in architectures and hosting, the rise of the advertising supported web, and what a more peer-to-peer future holds.

Update: DrupalCon Global has been rescheduled as a fully online, distributed conference. I will miss the opportunity to catch up with many people in person. But I have been lucky enough to have my Drupal and the Decentralized Web session accepted as a "live" talk, taking place on July 14th at 23:15 UTC / 4:15pm PDT / 7:15pm EDT. Please join me at the conference and for my session, I've added it as an event on our forum as well.

Back in 2003, I joined drupal.org, posted about wrapping recipe.module with CSS classes, and the rest is history.

I went on to host Dries in Vancouver in 2004, along with the first printed Drupal t-shirts, a beer tower, and the folks from DeanSpace / CivicSpace (working on the Democratic primaries) flew up to join us.

Allow me some brief nostalgia‚Ä¶

I founded Bryght, one of the first commercial companies focused on Drupal, helped organize many more DrupalCons and DrupalCamps, and helped found the Drupal Association.

We were in the thick of Web 1.0 transitioning to Web 2.0, and the early days of identity standards and communication between websites. That post I made about the recipe.module is actually tied to a Blogger.com account, which at the time you could use to login to drupal.org.

Open source licenses and the details of GPL were hotly contested, and we faced a lot of FUD from Microsoft and others. A global community using mailing lists and IRC was forming, and we didn't know what we were doing was new and different, but that we had come for the code and were staying for the community.

Now, I see Web3 emerging ‚Äì although the blog post where I attempt to define what that means to me still isn't finished yet!

New open source licenses are emerging (Dries on Makers and Takers), business models beyond the advertising supported web are being sought for.

Advances in computer science theory have given us new tools for distributed systems and cryptography, leading to both better privacy and programmable Internet money.

Dries' post on low-code and no code tools shows more changes that I think fit into this theme:

When everyone is a builder, more good things will happen on the web. I was excited about this trend more than 12 years ago, and remain excited today. I'm eager to see the progress no-code and low-code solutions will bring to the web in the next decade.

The Drupal community has long been eager to experiment with new technology and standards. How will Drupal's traditional LAMP stack architecture fit with serverless and decentralized approaches? What new standards and protocols make sense to integrate and expand on?

What new experiences do they enable that offer benefits for everyone from site builders to Drupal end users?

Please join me in Minneapolis for my presentation Drupal and the Decentralized Web. Check out the full list of speakers and accepted sessions.

I'd love to catch up with many of you that I haven't seen for years, and to meet many new members of the Drupal community.

Want to find out more about what we're up to with Fission? You can read the latest newsletter in our forum, or drop into our Discord chat to come say "hi" (plus I'm in the Drupal Slack, too).

node.title: Brooke presenting at √òREDEV 2019 in Malm√∂, Sweden
node.excerpt:
We're pleased to announce that Brooke [/author/expede/]  will be presenting at
the √òREDEV Developer Conference [https://oredev.org/]  in Malm√∂, Sweden,
November 6 - 8th, 2019.

Her talks in the Polyglot & Fringe sections will cover her work with Elixir and
Haskell, as well as decentralized web work with IPFS and beyond.

Early bird tickets are available now ¬ª [https://oredev.org/tickets/]

We keep track of interesting developer events and those we are organizing and
speaking at in our Events Cal

node.title: FISSION at the Seattle Ethereum meetup
node.excerpt: Brooke & Boris will be speaking at the Seattle Ethereum Meetup on May 28th. Plus: cyperpunk speakeasy drinks with xDAI Burner Wallet!
node.custom_excerpt: Brooke & Boris will be speaking at the Seattle Ethereum Meetup on May 28th. Plus: cyperpunk speakeasy drinks with xDAI Burner Wallet!

tags.description: Events in the decentralized web, p2p, & Ethereum community.

node.plaintext:
FISSION is excited to be featured at the Seattle Ethereum Meetup Tuesday, May
28th. 

Brooklyn will be presenting on IPFS and how FISSION is using it to build
‚Äúhostless‚Äù apps. The InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is an incredibly powerful
new protocol that gives every piece of data its own unique address. It‚Äôs also
more immutable than the way many smart contracts work.

Boris recently wrote about the layers of Ethereum Governance
[https://blog.bmannconsulting.com/ethereum-governance/], and has a long history
of involvement with open source. He will talk about participating in the
Ethereum Community, the ETH1x roadmap, and how anyone can learn to contribute to
open source communities.

The theme is Cypherpunk Speakeasy, and there will be xDAI and Burner Wallets.
Kurt Barry, a software engineer from MakerDAO, will be giving a primer on DAI,
the crypto we will be using for payments.

Seattle Ethereum's First Cypherpunk Speakeasy!
Tuesday, May 28, 2019, 6:30 PM

Ada's Lab
425 15th Avenue E Seattle, wa

42 Ethers Attending  
 Get ready - it's Seattle's first Cypherpunk Speakeasy! We will be using burner
wallets loaded with dai to buy drinks and listen to some awesome speakers.
Haven't used a burner wallet before? Its the easiest, most user friendly
onboarding experience to using crypto. These events have been held all over the
world and we are excited to bring it to Sea...

Check out this Meetup ‚Üí
[https://www.meetup.com/Seattle-Ethereum-Meetup/events/261257880/]

Sign up for the event on the Seattle Ethereum Meetup ¬ª
[https://www.meetup.com/Seattle-Ethereum-Meetup/events/261257880/]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CypherPunk Speakeasy
node.html:
FISSION is excited to be featured at the Seattle Ethereum Meetup Tuesday, May 28th.

Brooklyn will be presenting on IPFS and how FISSION is using it to build ‚Äúhostless‚Äù apps. The InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is an incredibly powerful new protocol that gives every piece of data its own unique address. It‚Äôs also more immutable than the way many smart contracts work.

Boris recently wrote about the layers of Ethereum Governance, and has a long history of involvement with open source. He will talk about participating in the Ethereum Community, the ETH1x roadmap, and how anyone can learn to contribute to open source communities.

The theme is Cypherpunk Speakeasy, and there will be xDAI and Burner Wallets. Kurt Barry, a software engineer from MakerDAO, will be giving a primer on DAI, the crypto we will be using for payments.
